dialogues.MAYA:
[1]I'm fine. She's not. 
[2]No, we should go back in. Something about the strange intensity of her expression makes Daniel reconsider and he turns back to the interrogation room. 
[3]You're not wearing one. Is he ever getting out? 
[4]That's not credible. 
[5]You too, Sir. 
[6]Fine. 
[7]It's kinda fucked up. 9. 
[8]No. Bradley smiles. He knew she didn't volunteer. They reach a secure area and Bradley checks Maya through an electronic door. 
[9]That's pre-9/11 behavior. Jessica doesn't appreciate the challenge. 
[10]We invaded Afghanistan. That's a reason. And so the rivalry begins. 
[11]You can help yourself by being truthful. The door handle turns. It occurs to Maya that perhaps Daniel was testing her resilience, too, as Daniel re-enters with a DOG COLLAR in his hand. 
[12]Ammar doesn't have a clue about what happened. 
[13]How? 
[14]He's not going to talk about attacks on the homeland. He's going to withhold operational details on the KSM network and probably on bin Laden.  But he's been in complete isolation, he doesn't know we failed. We can tell him anything. 
[15]He hasn't slept, Dan. He's clueless. 
[16]After we kept you awake for 96 hours, you gave us names of some of your brothers and saved the lives of a lot of innocent people. 
[17]Sorry, who is the "we" in that sentence? 
[18]Who's Abu Ahmed? I've heard of the other guys. 
[19]What's his family name? 
[20]Abu Ahmed means "father of Ahmed", it's a kunya. 21. 
[21]Ammar, I know the difference between a war name and an Arabic name. 
[22]A letter? 
[23]Fine. 
[24]You're assuming that Al Qaeda members are motivated by financial rewards. They're radicals. 
[25]Money for walk-ins worked great in the cold war, I'll give you that. 
[26]Just not sure those tactics are applicable to the Middle East. 
[27]Who did he work for? Hakim translates. Then the prisoner speaks. 
[28]What did he do for Faraj? 
[29]We need to ask him something to see if he's telling the truth. We don't know if he really knew Faraj. Hakim speaks to the prisoner. 
[30]Twenty detainees recognize that photo of Abu Ahmed. They say he's part of the inner circle of guys who were hanging out in Afghanistan pre-9/11. A lot of them say that after 9/11, he went to work for KSM. When KSM got captured, he went to work for Abu Faraj, primarily as a courier from Faraj to bin Laden. 
[31]Yeah, we don't know if Abu is on the outside of the network - part of a series of cutouts and dead drops - or if he has a direct connection to bin Laden. Does bin Laden invite him into the living room and hand him a letter directly? Or is Abu just the last guy in a long line of couriers, so that's why everybody knows him? 28. 
[32]We know that he's important. The fact that everybody's heard of Abu Ahmed but nobody will tell me where he is suggests that. 
[33]No. 
[34]No. 
[35]I want you to understand that I know you. I have been following you and studying you for a long time. I chased you in Lahore. We find Maya entering the gates of a Pakistani prison. The weather makes the place seem especially bleak. 
[36]I had you picked up instead of killing you because you're not a violent man and you don't deserve to die. 
[37]But you do have deep ties to Al Qaeda that I want to ask you about before you get sent to your next location, which might be Israel. Ghul looks ashen. 
[38]However, depending on how candid you are today, I may be able to keep you in Pakistan. 
[39]I'm going to ask you a series of questions based on your knowledge of Al Qaeda and your position as key financier for the organization. 
[40]What can you tell me about Atiyah Abd al-Rahman. 
[41]In what context have you ever heard the name Abu Ahmed? 
[42]What makes you say that? 
[43]Where did you last see him, and where is he now? 
[44]Why is that? 
[45]Seriously? Thank you. 
[46]Deal. 
[47]You want family ties, financial networks, media sources, disgruntled employees, imminent threats, homeland plots, 
[48]Foreign cells, health status, trade craft, recruiting tactics -- anything else? 
[49]A lot of brothers told us Abu Ahmed was bin Laden's courier and that he worked very closely with you. 35. 
[50]Who? 
[51]Okay, so you're telling me that all the other brothers are wrong, and there's some famous Buluchi guy that is working for you and bin Laden that I've never even heard of? 
[52]What does this Buluchi guy look like? 
[53]Kind of like Gandolf? 
[54]When was the last time you saw him? 
[55]I don't believe you. The GUARD in the room with them leans forward and SLAPS Faraj across the face. Faraj's expression doesn't change and Maya herself remains flat and steady, unmoved by the violence. She's not quite the same young lady she was a few years ago. 36. 
[56]You're not being fulsome in your replies. 
[57]You do realize this is not a normal prison. You determine how you are treated, and your life will be very uncomfortable until you give me information I need. The guard slaps Faraj again. Faraj is impassive. 
[58]Faraj is completely denying knowing Abu Ahmed, and that's using every measure we have. 
[59]Do you want to take a run at him? 
[60]No? Since when? 
[61]What? You okay? 
[62]Like what? 
[63]I'm not going to find Abu Ahmed from 
[64]Sorry, Dan. 
[65]I know. 38. 
[66]To the Marriott. I assume you noticed the dip plates. 
[67]It's a gym bag. Maya does not get out of the car. She stares at him defiantly. He advances forward a bit. She rolls up her window, flicks the door lock, and starts dialing her cell phone. The policeman walks away to rejoin his group. The police confer. The original policeman returns, this time with several other cops. They knock on the glass. Hard. Maya stares straight ahead. 
[68]Fucking checkpoints. Maya sits down, absorbed in her Blackberry. 
[69]Yeah. 
[70]Okay. 
[71]No, it's not. 
[72]I can work on it at the same time - plus I think it's a good thing that he lied. 
[73]You sound just like Bradley. He doesn't believe in my lead either. 40. 
[74]It's a good thing because the fact that Faraj withheld on Abu Ahmed is revealing. The only other thing he lied about was the location of bin Laden himself. That means Faraj thinks Abu Ahmed in as important to protect as bin Laden. That confirms my lead. 
[75]He's probably stuck in some check- point somewhere. 
[76]Hello, I work with him. I'm not that girl, that fucks. It's unbecoming. 
[77]What? Jessica pops a CD into Maya's computer, loads a file that plays the same video clip we have just seen. 
[78]Shut the fuck up! The camera stops on one man, BALAWI. 
[79]This could be it! 
[80]You're right. We can't rely on the Jords. We have to evaluate him face to face. 
[81]The key is to meet him so we can figure out for ourselves what he can actually do. 
[82]Can't or won't? 44. 
[83]He knows we're white. You'll get kidnapped up there. DAVID, an analyst, adds his two cents to the conversation - 
[84]I don't want to be a straphangar. It's your show. You were the first to see the potential in this. 
[85]Cool. Bring me back a bottle. 
[86]I don't believe this. 
[87]I'm going to smoke everybody involved in this op, and then I'm going to kill bin Laden. Off the darkness in her eyes we - 
[88]Doesn't matter, but I wish I had that five years ago. How come I never saw it before? 
[89]Don't eat out. It's too dangerous. Maya stares at the Al Quaeda mugshots - a thought crosses her mind. 
[90]Dan, Debbie found Abu Ahmed! 
[91]He was in the files this whole time. The family name is Sayeed. 
[92]We have no intercepts about Abu Ahmed dying. 55. 
[93]We just have a detainee who buried somebody who looked like Abu Ahmed. But if somebody as important as Abu Ahmed had died, they'd be talking about it online in chat rooms all over the place. Plus, the detainee said that Habeeb died in 2001. We know that Abu Ahmed was alive then, trying to get into Tora Bora with Ammar. That means it's probably one of the other brothers that's dead. 
[94]Yes, I fucking want it to be true. Maya slams the desk. 
[95]I am calm. 
[96]Move heaven and earth and bring me this fucking Sayeed family's phone number. 
[97]Hey, Jack. 59. 
[98]Fuck. She dashes out runs down the hall to an Exit sign - bursts through the door to a staircase - 
[99]How come you haven't deployed a team to stay in Rawalpindi? 
[100]That's why you should forward deploy - so you can shorten your response time. 
[101]Why? 
[102]You haven't tried. 
[103]That's bullshit. 
[104]Right, I understand. But I don't really care if your guys get sleep or not. Maya looks at Larry's team sleeping on the couch. 
[105]Abu Ahmed al Kuwaiti is the nom de guerre. His true name, we think, is Ibraheem Sayeed. His family lives in Kuwait. 
[106]I know - 
[107]Over the course of two months, he's called home from six different pay phones, from two different cities, never using the same phone twice. And when his mother asked him where he was, he lied. He said that he was in a place in the country with bad cell reception -- implying he was in the Tribals -- but he was in 61. 
[108]a market in Peshawar. I'm sorry, but that's not normal guy behavior. That's tradecraft. 
[109]No. Not okay. Look, Abu Ahmed is too smart to tip his hand by talking about ops on the phone: he works for bin Laden. The guys that talk about ops on the phone don't get that job. Larry looks away. 
[110]A lot of my friends have died trying to do this. I believe I was spared so I could finish the job. The girl is a true believer - as pure as they come. Larry looks at her. Her sincerity is persuasive. And just like that, he decides to help her. 
[111]I really need to talk to you about beefing up our surveillance operation on the caller. 
[112]He's the key to bin Laden. 
[113]bin Laden is the one who keeps telling them to attack the homeland. 63. 
[114]If it wasn't for him, Al Qaeda would still be focused on overseas targets. If you really want to protect the homeland, you need to get bin Laden. 
[115]You just want me to nail some low level Mullah-crack-a-dulla so that you can check that box on your resume that says while you were in Pakistan you got a real terrorist. But the truth is you don't understand Pakistan, and you don't know Al Qaeda. Either give me the team I need to follow this lead, or the other thing you're gonna have on your resume is being the first Station Chief to be called before a congressional committee for subverting the efforts to capture or kill bin Laden. 
[116]I need four techs in a safe house in Rawalpindi and four techs in a safe house in Peshawar. Either send them out or send me back to DC and explain to the Director why you did it. 
[117]I love you! 
[118]It would be convenient for him to drop tapes off if he's sending either from bin Laden or from an intermediary. When he wants to make a call, he leaves the house, walks a few blocks, then switches on the phone. We need to keep canvassing the neighborhood until we find him. 65. 
[119]Do you think its intentional? 
[120]ISI fucked you. I'm so sorry Joseph. It's the first time she's addressed him by his first name. Startling, to hear kindness in her voice. Joseph turns to reply then thinks better of it and walks away. 
[121]Is this what I think it is? 
[122]Thank you! 
[123]I need a picket line along the GT highway and men spaced at intervals along the road and at every exit. 71. 
[124]So you agree with me now. This is important? 
[125]Our current hypothesis is that he lives somewhere along the highway, in one of the towns, or a medium sized city called Abbottabod, or up near Kashmir. ECU: mango cart. Nestled among the fruit is a BLACK RADIO. 
[126]Kashmir is interesting because it's a way station for the Tribals. We stay with the old man for a while. At last, the white POTAHAR SUV drives past. He makes a note in his pad. 
[127]Abbottabod is interesting because we know from detainee reporting that Faraj stayed there, briefly in 2003. 
[128]The good news is he's driving a white SUV. SUV's are actually pretty rare in Pakistan. If he was driving a sedan or a compact, we'd be fucked. 
[129]Obviously this assumes he doesn't change vehicles. Maya at her desk working and we realize that she has been typing all this in a cable she will email to Washington. 
[130]Good morning, Amad. Maya gets in her car. The gate opens. As she starts pulling out onto the street, suddenly a car drives up in front of her and THREE SHOOTERS come out and hammer Maya's Toyota. 
[131]Any American in Pakistan is a target, they don't necessarily know I'm CIA. 
[132]Yeah. 
[133]Pretty much. 
[134]The question isn't are the Paks protecting bin Laden?' 75. 
[135]The question is, 'would he allow himself to be protected by the Paks?' I mean, why would he trust them? He tried to kill Musharaf. Steve considers a reply, but the meeting principals are filing in, including Daniel, and when Steve sees the CIA DIRECTOR enter the room, he clears the head of the table. 
[136]I'm the motherfucker that found this place, Sir. The boss studies her for a moment then turns back to the model. 
[137]Morning, George. In red magic marker, Maya writes the number 21 on the glass. Then circles it. George looks up. 
[138]Twenty-one days. It's been twenty- one days since we found the house and nothing's happened! 
[139]Yeah? 
[140]Who's that? 
[141]How do you know the gender? 78. 
[142]What's that up there? (pointing to the other 
[143]Your female is moving fast. 
[144]So you found two males, three females? 
[145]You're missing a male. 
[146]Wow. 
[147]There are two narratives about the location of Osama bin Laden. This registers on the SEALs. 
[148]The one that you're most familiar with is that UBL is hiding in a cave in the Tribal Areas, that he's surrounded by a large contingent of loyal fighters. Beat. 
[149]But that narrative is pre- 9/11 understanding of UBL. The second narrative is that he's living in a city - living in a city with multiple points of egress and entries and with access to communications so that he can keep in touch with the organization. You can't run a global network of inter- connected cells from a cave. Beat. 
[150]We've located an individual we believe based on detainee reporting is bin Laden's courier. He's living in a house in Abbottabod, Pakistan. And we assess that one of the other occupants of the house is UBL. 
[151]No. 86. 
[152]Bin Laden uses a courier to interact with the outside world. By locating the courier, we've located bin Laden. 
[153]Quite frankly, I didn't even want to use you guys, with your dip and your velcro and all your gear bullshit. I wanted to drop a bomb but people didn't believe in this lead enough to drop a bomb, so they're using you guys as canaries on the theory that if bin Laden isn't there, you can sneak away and no one will be the wiser. But bin Laden is there - and you're going to kill him for me. 
[154]We've spun up the SEALs - we've done everything humanly possible to collect on the compound, and the collection is not going to get any better. 
[155]You're going to come into work one day, and there's going to be a black moving van and a 'for sale' sign in front of that compound. George drops his tray down. 
[156]One hundred percent, he's there - okay, fine, ninety-five percent because I know certainty freaks you guys out - but it's a hundred! 89. 
[157]Twelve years. I was recruited out of high school. 
[158]I don't think I can answer that question, sir. I don't think I'm allowed to answer. 
[159]Nothing. I've done nothing else. He evaluates her... weighing her certainty against his decades of Washington experience. 90. 
[160]When? 
[161]Testing - testing 1 - 2 - 3 - A SEAL with his com set on gives her the thumbs up. She looks around at all the impressive technology in the makeshift Command Center. She walks over to Hakim and they leave together. 
[162]Thank you for coming with me. 
[163]Fuck Hakim, what if I'm wrong? 92. 
[164]I wish we could have just dropped a bomb. 
[165]I'm serious. 
[166]Pakistani coms, no chatter. 
[167]Yeah.
dialogues.DANIEL:
[1]I own you, Ammar. You belong to me. Look at me. This is DANIEL STANTON, the CIA's man in Islamabad - a big American, late 30's, with a long, anarchical beard snaking down to his tattooed neck. He looks like a paramilitary hipster, a punk rocker with a Glock. 
[2]If you don't look at me when I talk to you, I hurt you. If you step off this mat, I hurt you. If you lie to me, I'm gonna hurt you. Now, Look at me. His prisoner, AMMAR, stands on a decaying gym mat, surrounded by four GUARDS whose faces are covered in ski masks. Ammar looks down. Instantly: the guards rush Ammar, punching and kicking. 
[3]Look at me, Ammar. Notably, one of the GUARDS wearing a ski mask does not take part in the beating. 2. 
[4]Are we gonna board up these windows or what? Just off the plane from Washington, you're rocking your best suit for your first interrogation, and then you get this guy. It's not always this intense. 
[5]Just so you know, it's going to take awhile. He has to learn how helpless he is. Let's get a coffee. 
[6]You know, there's no shame if you wanna watch from the monitor. She shakes her head. 
[7]Alright. At the door, Daniel hands the ski mask back to Maya. 
[8]You might want to put this on. 3. 
[9]Never. 
[10]Right now, this is about you coming to terms with your situation. It's you and me, bro. I want you to understand that I know you, that I've been studying you for a very long time. I could have had you killed Karachi. But I let you live so you and I could talk. 
[11]Life isn't always fair, my friend. Did you really think that when we got you, I'd be a nice fucking guy? 
[12]And you're a money man. A paperboy! Daniel paces around Ammar, anger rising. 
[13]A disgrace to humanity! 4. 
[14]You and your uncle murdered three thousand innocent people. I have your name on a five-thousand dollar transfer via Western Union to a 9/11 hijacker. He leans into Ammar's ear. Uncomfortably close. 
[15]And you got popped with 150 kilograms of high explosives in your house! 
[16]I'm just fucking with you. Beat. He laughs again. 
[17]I don't want to talk about 9/11. What I want to focus on is the Saudi group. Daniel shows him a photo. 
[18]That there is Hazem al-Kashmiri. And I know this dude is up to some serious shit, and what I want from you is his Saudi email. Feel free to jump in. Ammar, bro, I know that you know this dude, just give me his email...and I will give you a blanket. I will give you a blanket and some solid food. No response from Ammar. Daniel starts putting on his gloves. 
[19]I know that you know him. 
[20]Have it your way. 5. 
[21]Let's go. It all happens in a flash: in one swift motion, Daniel pushes Ammar to the floor, the guards pin his limbs, and Daniel smothers Ammar's face with a towel. Ammar thrashes. Daniel considers his next move. 
[22]Grab the bucket. Maya follows Daniel's gesture to the corner of the room, where there's an ICE CHEST filled with WATER and a PLASTIC 
[23]Put some water in it. She dips the pitcher in the water, hands shaking. 
[24]C'mon, let's go. The stress and strain on her face is enormous as she brings the bucket back to Daniel. Daniel starts pouring the water on Ammar's face, which is now covered by a towel. Ammar thrashes with rising panic. 
[25]Hazem was a friend of Ramzi Yousef, you guys met in Tunisia back in the 70s. 
[26]You're a terrorist, that's why I'm doing it to you. 6. 
[27]I want emails of the rest of the Saudi group. Give me emails of the rest of the Saudi group! Give me one email, and I will stop this! Ammar doesn't speak. He can't. 
[28]Who's in the Saudi group, and what's the target? Where was the last time you saw bin Laden? WHERE WAS THE 
[29]This is what defeat looks like, bro. Your jihad is over. Daniel stands. 
[30]Get him up. The guards bring Ammar to his feet. Daniel, shifting his persona yet again, touches Ammar's face and speaks to him with the comforting tenor of a therapist. 
[31]Try to understand the concept here. I have time, you don't. I have other things to do, you don't. It's cool that you're strong. I respect it, I do. But in the end, everybody breaks, bro. It's biology. Dan and Maya exit. They've learned nothing. 
[32]It was good. The local cops need tactical help. But he's Tier fucking One, baby. There's your money maker. 
[33]He's being a dick. 
[34]I am going to have to turn up the heat. He needs to give us the Saudi group now. They reach the lobby, where they can see Maya sitting in the holding area. They walk towards her as Bradley considers what Daniel is asking for. 8. 
[35]Tight with his uncle, prints all over the 9/11 money. Daniel knocks on the glass for Maya to come in. 
[36]Was I lying or what? The guard opens the door and Maya comes through - not many females come through that door. 
[37]Maya, this is Joseph Bradley, our illustrious station chief.  Joe and I did Iraq together. 
[38]She's been having a great time ever since she got in, isn't that right? 
[39]Don't you think she's a little young for the hard stuff? 
[40]The children's crusade. 
[41]They're slow rolling us in Lahore - you might want to bitch about that. 
[42]Dude, I've been in a dark room with another man for the last two days. 
[43]Everyone, this is Maya. Maya, everyone. 11. 
[44]Please don't ask how it's going with Ammar because she's not going to fucking tell you. 
[45]- Best man for it. 
[46]Any imminent threats in here? 
[47]And that's a conversation? Jessica shrugs. At this point, she believes that it is merely a conversation - not a fully realized plot. 12. 
[48]I think he'll give up the Saudis. But Heathrow is gonna be tough. Anyway. Anything from last night? 
[49]Great. 
[50]I agree, I spoke to the Chief about that. Anything on bin Laden? 
[51]No, don't need him, the diamond sighting is bullshit. See if the Paks will send someone to talk to the farmer. Anything else? We need to be putting runs on the board against Faraj. Speak to the case officers who didn't see fit to make it today. And thank them. 
[52]Let's take it easy today, huh? Daniel hands Ammar a bottle of orange juice and a bag of falafel. 
[53]Hungry? The food in here sucks so I got you some of this. Ammar grabs the lunch sack and scarfs down the falafels. 
[54]Richard Reid, wow. I was thinking about him. The guy gets a bomb in his shoe on a plane. Unbelievable. You know him, don't you? Slowly, Ammar nods. 14. 
[55]I'm glad you said that. I have an email from you to him. I've had all your coms for years, bro. Who else is in your Saudi group? 
[56]When you lie to me, I hurt you. 
[57]I believe you. I do, I believe you. Beat. 
[58]Do you want the water again, or do you want something else? 
[59]Just give me a name. 
[60]You see how this works? You don't mind if my female colleague sees your junk, do you? Daniel pulls down Ammar's pants. Maya flinches at the bare nakedness. 
[61]Dude, you shit your pants. 15. Daniel turns to Maya - 
[62]You stay here, I'll be back. Daniel goes out, leaving Maya standing alone in front of the naked, chained man. Ammar looks at her imploringly and she struggles to meet his eyes. 
[63]This is a dog collar. Daniel unhooks Ammar, snaps the collar and leash around his neck, as Ammar cries out against the humiliation. Maya flinches. Daniel is relentless: 
[64]You determine how I treat you. Now Daniel drags Ammar on all fours, pulling him by the leash. 
[65]I'm going to walk you. Maya watches in horror as Daniel walks Ammar to a far corner of the room, then leans down to address his victim: 
[66]What the fuck do you think is going on, Ammar? Wahleed has already told me that you know. At last, Daniel reaches an area of the room where there is a large wooden box resting on a platform. 16. 
[67]This box sucks. I'm going to put you in it. Ammar tries to speak but can't get a word out. 
[68]When is the attack? 
[69]Sunday? Sunday where? This Sunday or next Sunday? Ammar mumbles, almost inaudibly. 
[70]Is it Sunday or Monday? Ammar doesn't answer. The masked men approach. 
[71]Which day is it? Partial information is treated as a lie. 
[72]Ammar, which day? 
[73]Yeah, now. 18. 
[74]Who said that? Zied? Fuck him. This is on me. Ammar is on me!! And it's on her!!  We can't let this be a win-win for 
[75]Bluff him? 
[76]You don't remember, do you? You - me: same same. Bad memory. While GUARDS move in the deep b.g., Daniel and Maya are seated at a picnic table with an appetizing spread of Arabic food. 
[77]Which is the smart thing to do, you're starting to think for yourself. Ammar is lost. But the food is tempting. 
[78]Eat up! You earned it. Ammar eats. 
[79]So you flew via Amman to Kabul to hang out with your uncle? Mukhtar. 
[80]I told you man, I know you. Alright, you got me - flight manifests. It must've been pretty fucked up for you guys after 9/11. What did you do after the invasion and before you went back to Pesh? 20. 
[81]You chose to fight. Ammar looks Daniel right in the eyes. 
[82]I can eat with some other dude and hook you back up to the ceiling? 
[83]She got you there, dude. 
[84]What did it say? Daniel offers Ammar a smoke. 
[85]Cigarette? Ammar accepts. Daniel's lights it. 
[86]We don't know what we don't know. 
[87]It's a tautology. 
[88]What do you like? Bob Marley? Reggae? Egyptian music? Just let me know, if there's music you like, I can make a call. 
[89]Can I be honest with you? I'm bad news. I'm not your friend. I'm not gonna help you. I'm gonna break you. Beat. 
[90]I've done it before.  Hey, wake up. You haven't eaten in 18 hours, we've got to keep your energy up. You hungry? 
[91]He's either going to withhold or die from the pressure you're putting on him. 
[92]No. 37. 
[93]You know, I've been meaning to tell you: I'm getting outta here. 
[94]I'm fine. I've just seen too many guys naked. It's gotta be over a hundred at this point. I need to go do something normal for awhile. 
[95]Go to Washington, do the dance, see how that environment works. You should come with me. Be my number two. You're looking a little strung out yourself. Maya looks at Dan. No longer the man he once was. She doesn't hide her disappointment. 
[96]They killed my monkeys. Something about an escape. Can you fucking believe that? 
[97]Look, Maya, you gotta be really careful with detainees now. The politics are changing and you don't want to be the last one holding a dog collar when the oversight committee comes. 
[98]And watch your back when you get back to Pakistan. Everyone knows you there now. 
[99]Fuck. Really? 
[100]Ok, but he's dead. So doesn't that make him a little less interesting to you? 
[101]Okay, what are you basing this on? 
[102]As-Salamu alaykum. 56. 
[103]I need a couple hundred thousand. Four max. 
[104]From you. 
[105]This could crack open the facilitator Maya's been looking for by giving us a phone number. She's your killer, Wolf. You put her on the field. (reciting a phrase from the KORAN, in Arabic, then loosely 
[106]I ran it. I'll defend it. 
[107]It's good to be back in Kuwait. It's good to see you again, it's been awhile. The businessman doesn't answer. 
[108]I need a favor. 
[109]Because we're friends. 
[110]Fair enough. How about a V10 Lamborghini? How's that for friendship? 
[111]
[112]Is this a Balboni? Fuck me. This is nice. What are you thinking? 
[113]That's a nice choice, my friend. Daniel gives the Kuwaiti a slip of paper. 
[114]Who do you think? The guy's a terrorist. His mother lives here. I just need her phone number. 
[115]Somebody might die at some point in Pakistan. They shake hands. 
[116]Well, I agree with sixty, we're basing this mostly on detainee reporting and I spent a bunch of time in those rooms - who knows? Maya shoots Daniel a look. What a traitor. 
[117]I'd say it's a soft sixty, sir. I'm virtually certain there's some high value target there, I'm just not sure it's bin Laden. The CIA Director leans back in his chair.
dialogues.JESSICA:
[1]Here we go. 
[2]Right, but you forgot - you forgot Mullah Omar. J.J. and JEREMY, two case officers, continue the banter: 
[3]Ammar is withholding? Daniel nods. 
[4]
[5]The Jordanians are being really helpful with Ammar's transit papers. Jessica passes Daniel a file. 
[6]They want the Consulate, the Marriott, it's low security. And they've got Majid Kahn talking about gas stations in the US. 
[7]Honestly? There are six hundred questions in there. I'd concentrate on Heathrow. The Saudis. Does it matter what Faraj thinks about Heathrow? How much latitude does he get to pick targets?

[32]This is it.

[40]I'm not. Believe me. We're stuck. 
[41]This may be going overboard, but I baked him a cake! 
[42]Don't be so literal. Everyone likes cake. It's not too late for you to come, you know. It will be fun. 
[43]Come on! We've got lots of wine! The target on Maya's monitor disappears in a puff of smoke. 
[44]I will. 
[45]Not to get technical, but this guy is actually the first big break we've had since 9/11. To big breaks and the little people that make them happen. Clink. 46. 
[46]So far, everything he's said we've cross checked and it's proved legit... and I think the money is persuasive. 25 million dollars?! That buys a new life. 
[47]Possibly. But Al Qaeda needs doctors and they are short staffed and that could explain his rise. In six months to a year, if he doesn't fuck up, he could be called in to treat bin Laden. And at that moment, with 25 mil on the table, I think he gives up the Big Man. And if he doesn't, we kill him. 
[48]So John?  When he arrives, I'll set the tone, and then I'll flip it to you - and you'll talk about asset protection. 
[49]Then Lauren, I know you want to get some questions in there - but give Balawi time after John speaks. We'll cover the basics and have his birthday cake, then we'll get to the nitty gritty. 47. Jessica turns to Zied.

[55]I just need them to go away for a minute. You can search him as soon as he gets here. The Security Guard pauses, then into his radio:
dialogues.BRADLEY:

dialogues.GEORGE:
[1]I want to make something absolutely clear. 52. 
[2]If you thought there was some secret cell somewhere working Al Qaeda, I want you to know that you're wrong. This is it. There's no working group coming to the rescue. He stares at his staff. 
[3]There's nobody else, hidden away on some other floor. There is just us. And we are failing. We're spending billions of dollars. People are dying. We're still no closer to defeating our enemy. 
[4]They attacked us on land in 98, by sea in 2000, and from the air in 2001. They murdered three thousand of our citizens in cold blood, and they've slaughtered our forward deployed. And what the fuck have we done about it? What have we done? We have twenty leadership names and we've only eliminated four of them. Beat. 
[5]I want targets! Do your fucking jobs, bring me people to kill! 
[6]It will probably be discovered. 
[7]The PMA - The Pakistan Military Academy. It's their West Point. 
[8]About a mile. A WOMAN'S voice from the back of the room. 76. 
[9]If there are three females, there ought to be three males. Observant Muslim women either live with parents or with their husbands. We think there's a third family living in the house.

[11]We talked about burrowing a pin hole camera but there's a high risk of discovery. 80. 
[12]We have explored the possibility of digging tunnels, of sending hot air balloons, of re-routing supply C- 130's to take a peek, but that might be too alerting. We've looked for ways of collecting available DNA from his trash - you know, looking for his toothbrush, but they burn the trash. We started a vaccination program, we sent a doctor to the house, to see if he could pull blood. A lady in a black burkha rushes out and angrily shoos the doctor away. 
[13]That didn't work out. We thought about sending a guy with a bucket to pull a sample from the sewer to analyze his fecal matter. 
[14]What was wrong with that? The sample would be too diluted. 
[15]They don't make telephone calls from the compound. We pulled the cell tower nearby. 
[16]The unidentified third male does not get groceries. He does not leave the compound. He does not present himself for photographs. 81. 
[17]When he needs fresh air, he paces around beneath a grape arbor, but the leaves are so thick they obscure our satellite views. This is a professional attempt to avoid detection - real tradecraft. The only people we've seen behave this way are other top level Al Qaeda operatives. The National Security Advisor nods to his Special Assistant who slides a big folder across his desk to George. 
[18]You know we lost our ability to prove that when we lost the detainee program. Who the hell am I supposed to ask? Some guy in Gitmo who is all lawyered up? He'll just tell his lawyer to warn bin Laden. 
[19]He'd be the first successful drug dealer never to have dealt drugs. He has no internet access to the house. He makes no phone calls either in or out. Who's he selling to, who's he buying from, how's he making his money? And if you're going to say he's retired, I'd say where's his swimming pool, where's the gold cage with the falcons? And why does he send his courier to the two cities in Pakistan we most associate with Al Qaeda, that have nothing particularly to do with heroin production? The National Security Advisor taps his pencil impatiently. 83. 
[20]I have to admit, I just don't get the rhythms of politics. 
[21]You know, you're right, I agree with everything you just said. What I meant was, a man in your position, how do you evaluate the risk of not doing something, the risk of potentially letting bin Laden slip through your fingers? George shakes his head with an "aww shucks" kind of shake. 
[22]That is a fascinating question. George walks away. After a beat, the National Security advisor calls after him. 
[23]Gentlemen, can I have your attention? My name is George. I run the Af-Pak division at CTC, and I'm primary on this for the agency. This is a title fifty operation. 85.

[25]They are nervous downtown. I don't think we'll get approval this decision cycle. They look up and notice that Maya is standing outside George's office staring at them through the glass. She angrily wipes the number 128 off the window and changes it to 129. Wolf nods. 
[26]Oh yeah. 
[27]We have to keep working it. 
[28]Maya, you didn't prove it. 
[29]I'm at eighty percent. Their OPSEC is what convinces me. 
[30]Maya, I wanted you to hear it first. You know that thing we talked about? It's going to happen. 
[31]Tonight. Good luck. She hangs up, turns back to the SEALs, who are still playing horseshoes with the grace of young guys in their prime. Their lives are in her hands.

CU COMPUTER SCREEN: A PRISONER being interviewed by a CIA CASE OFFICER holds the photo of Abu Ahmed we've seen so many times.

dialogues.NATIONAL SECURITY ADVISOR:
[1]So this third male that you've identified as possibly being bin Laden, do I just give up all hope of ever seeing a photograph of him? 
[2]And it's asking too much to get a voice confirmation with him on the phone? 
[3]And I'm also going to give up hope that he might ever get in that white SUV and drive around a bit and we could see him? Don't they get groceries. 
[4]We did a Red Team on your analysis. According to them, this behavior could belong to someone other than Al Qaeda. 
[5]You get the point. If you can't prove it's bin Laden, at least prove it's not somebody else, like a drug dealer. Beat. The meeting is adjourned. As they walk out -- 82. 
[6]You'll think of something. 
[7]The President is a thoughtful, analytical guy. He needs proof. 
[8]You think this is political? If this was political we'd be having this conversation in October when there's an election bump. This is pure risk. Based on deductive reasoning, inference, supposition and the only human reporting you have is six years old, from detainees who are questioned under duress. The political move here is to tell you to go fuck yourself, and remind you that I was in the room when your old boss pitched WMD Iraq...at least there you guys brought photographs. 
[9]Hey. George turns around. The National Security Advisor approaches him. 84. 
[10]I'm not saying we're gonna do it. But the President wants to know: if we were going to act, how would we do it? Give us options.
dialogues.TECH:
[1]We're blocked. 
[2]Still on tower three! Five. Signal getting stronger. Ten! Larry continues driving straight down the main road. 
[3]Fifteen. Ten. Signal's getting weaker. We lost him - no signal. 
[4]He's up at five again. Fifteen. Twenty. Weaker now, he's shifted. We're back to five. I don't get it. 
[5]No. 
[6]Twenty. Thirty. Forty! Fifty - we're within ten meters of him. Larry scans the street - sees a half dozen guys on cell phones. 
[7]He's really close. 
[8]Could be. 70. 
[9]I got him.
dialogues.GHUL:
[1]Thank you. 31. 
[2]What do you want to know? 
[3]I have dealt with the mukhabarat, I have no wish to be tortured again. Ask me a question, I can answer it. 
[4]He works for Zawahiri. He's in charge of military tactics. 
[5]He works for Faraj and bin Laden. He is his most trusted courier. Maya works hard to hide how pleased she is to have this confirmation. She's not entirely successful. 
[6]He brought me many messages from the Sheikh. 32. 
[7]You will never find him. 
[8]Even I couldn't find him. He always contacted me out of the blue. He is one of the disappeared ones.
dialogues.PILOT:
[1]Ten minutes. 
[2]Three mikes to target. Standby for doors open. Inside the dim interior, illuminated by only blinking instrumentation, the men are tense, quiet. We pass slowly from face to face, noting each SEAL's contemplation of the mission that lies ahead. Some of them are anonymous soldiers. Many we've come to know: Justin, joyfully bobbing his head, grooving to his iPod... Saber's eyes fixed on a thousand-yard stare... Hakim struggles to get comfortable and control his anxiety, wipes away sweat... Patrick checks his gear for the hundredth time. 
[3]Should be coming up just off our nose, 3 o'clock. Everyone grabs onto their gear, getting ready to fast rope. 
[4]Thirty seconds. Patrick leans out for a visual as the wind rips his face - 
[5]Are you Maya? 
[6]That's the only name they gave me. You can sit wherever you want, you're the only one on the manifest. 111. Maya sits down, buckles in. The PILOT heads back to the 
[7]You must be pretty important, you got the whole plane to yourself! Beat. 
[8]Where do you want to go? She's speechless. Overwhelmed. Finally, she lets go. Those luminous eyes become pools of relief and pain.
dialogues.FARAJ:
[1]You're thinking of Abu Khalid. 
[2]Al Buluchi. My courier for the Sheikh. 
[3]Why should you have heard of him? 
[4]Tall, long white beard, thin. He uses a cane. 
[5]Who? 
[6]A month ago, in Karachi, but I don't know where he is now. Sometimes I wouldn't even see him, he would just tell me where to leave the messages. 
[7]You can't force me to tell you something I don't know.
dialogues.JARED:
[1]Hey Justin, what are you listening to? 
[2]Tony Robbins? 
[3]Ir-fah ee-dek! 
[4]Thanks. 
[5]Who is he? 
[6]
[7]Daughter, what is his name? The girl makes no reply.
dialogues.COMMANDING OFFICER:
[1]Negative. I'm internal, I'll let you in. The Commanding Officer opens the gate and the other SEALs walk inside. As a group, they move towards the main house, arriving at the South side front door. The door is open and they enter - 
[2]For God and Country, Geronimo. Maya gasps. 
[3]All Stations: target secure, target secure. 
[4]Target Secure - commence SSE. 
[5]Echo 05, this is Red 02, how long do you need for SSE? 
[6]You have four. 
[7]If you're not at the LZ in four, I'm going to leave your ass behind.
dialogues.SOLDIER INTERROGATOR:
[1]You and I are gonna talk about some of the guys in the training camps, yeah? The prisoner sits in a chair. He's hooded, but relaxed. 22. 
[2]Some of these brothers have done some bad things, and what I want to do is I want to separate them from the people like you. 
[3]There was a guy called Abu Ahmed from Kuwait. 
[4]How close was he? What was his relationship to the leadership? 
[5]Did he eat with you guys - did he eat with the good guys - or did he eat with the leadership? 
[6]Yes you do, you don't need an idea
dialogues.REPORTER:
[1]This is what remains of the #10 bus, which was traveling through Tavistock Square... 
[2]All around, groups of Londoners are standing on corners asking themselves 30. 
[3]The blast left a crater 10 meters wide in front of the hotel. The Marriott, one of the most popular destinations for locals and Westerners... 
[4]It is in surveillance video and pictures like this of the explosive- laden vehicle just moments before it was parked, that police hope to find the man who wanted so badly last night to leave a body count in Times Square. 
[5]Meanwhile, our chief foreign correspondent, Richard Engel, confirms the CIA's top spy in Pakistan has been pulled out of there. 
[6]He's been receiving death threats after being named publicly in a lawsuit by the family of a victim of a U.S. drone attack. 68.
dialogues.SECURTY GUARD:
[1]Quick question: all is taking place inside our main building? 
[2]Procedures only work if we follow them every time. 48. 
[3]Look, I'm responsible for everyone's safety, okay? It's not just about you. 
[4]All stations, go ahead and stand down. 
[5]Okay, he's coming. We're gonna search him when he gets here. Everyone prepares. The car gets closer and closer, a driver in front and a passenger in back. 
[6]Take your hand out of your pocket! Hey!
dialogues.WOLF:
[1]Alaykum salam. 
[2]Where you gonna get that? 
[3]You think so? 
[4]As you know, Abu Ghraib and Gitmo fucked us. The detainee program is now fly paper. We got senators jumping out of our asses, and the Director is very concerned. They will not stop until they have a body. There it is. The quid pro quo. There's a reason he's called The Wolf. Daniel considers all that he'll go through if he volunteers to be the fall guy for the controversial program. 
[5]It's her against the world. 87. 
[6]I concur. Sixty percent.
dialogues.SABER:
[1]That's not a door. 
[2]Khaled! Saber waits with his carbine raised. Anxiety crosses his face. He's vulnerable here, an easy target if Khaled were to come out blasting. 
[3]
[4]Osama! Osama!? Beat. Beat. Sweat on Saber's face 
[5]Osama!? A man appears at the end of the third floor hallway. -- Ssssht ! a bullet strikes him in the head - knocking him back into a bedroom - Saber fires again, missing - And proceeds down the hallway, going full speed now, Patrick right behind him, sprinting into the bedroom 
[6]I shot the third floor guy.
